title: Hillsborough police chief is failing to show emotion at trial because of his PTSD, judge tells jury
text:
The police chief who oversaw the Hillsborough stadium disaster is failing to show emotion at his trial because he suffers from PTSD, a judge has told a jury.

David Duckenfield, 75, is accused of the gross negligence manslaughter of 95 Liverpool supporters who died on an overcrowded terrace during a 1989 FA Cup fixture.

The retired chief superintendent was match-day commander when thousands of fans became trapped in a terrible crush in the Leppings Lane end of the stadium.

It is alleged his “extraordinarily bad” failings led to the deaths ahead of the ahead of Liverpool’s semi-final fixture against Nottingham Forest.

However, in an unusual move, the judge overseeing the trial at Preston Crown Court told the jury there may be a “medical explanation” if the defendant showed no emotion throughout the case.

Judge Sir Peter Openshaw directed the jury of eight women and four men not to draw an adverse inference from the demeanour of Duckenfield, who was sitting in the well of the court.

Speaking before evidence from Dolores Steele, whose 15-year-old son Philip died in the disaster, Sir Peter said: "My prediction is that Mr Duckenfield will show no emotion at all, because he has not shown any physical reaction at all throughout the trial.
description: The police chief who oversaw the Hillsborough stadium disaster is failing to show emotion at his trial because he suffers from PTSD, a judge has told a jury.
